column2: Don't tell any one you are gone, he called after her, with a voice far from feeble.
column3: Don't tell any one you are gone, he called after her, with a voice far from feeble.

column2: I don't want any of their damned company.
column3: I don't want any of their damned company.

column2: CHAPTER LIII.
column3: CHAPTER fifty three.

column2: A FRIEND IN NEED.
column3: A FRIEND IN NEED.

column2: Mary left the house, and saw no one on her way.
column3: Mary left the house, and saw no one on her way.

column2: But it was better, she said to herself, that he should lie there untended, than be waited on by unloving hands.
column3: But it was better, she said to herself, that he should lie there untended, than be waited on by unloving hands.

column2: The night was very dark.
column3: The night was very dark.

column2: There was no moon, and the stars were hidden by thick clouds.
column3: There was no moon, and the stars were hidden by thick clouds.

column2: She must walk all the way to Testbridge.
column3: She must walk all the way to Testbridge.

column2: She felt weak, but the fresh air was reviving.
column3: She felt weak, but the fresh air was reviving.

column2: She did not know the way so familiarly as that between Thornwick and the town, but she would enter the latter before arriving at the common.
column3: She did not know the way so familiarly as that between Thornwick and the town, but she would enter the latter before arriving at the common.

column2: She had not gone far when the moon rose, and from behind the clouds diminished the darkness a little.
column3: She had not gone far when the moon rose, and from behind the clouds diminished the darkness a little.

column2: The first part of her journey lay along a narrow lane, with a small ditch, a rising bank, and a hedge on each side.
column3: The first part of her journey lay along a narrow lane, with a small ditch, a rising bank, and a hedge on each side.

column2: About the middle of the lane was a farmyard, and a little way farther a cottage.
column3: About the middle of the lane was a farmyard, and a little way farther a cottage.

column2: Soon after passing the gate of the farmyard, she thought she heard steps behind her, seemingly soft and swift, and naturally felt a little apprehension; but her thoughts flew to the one hiding-place for thoughts and hearts and lives, and she felt no terror. At the same time something moved her to quicken her pace.
column3: Soon after passing the gate of the farmyard, she thought she heard steps behind her, seemingly soft and swift, and naturally felt a little apprehension; but her thoughts flew to the one hiding place for thoughts and hearts and lives, and she felt no terror. At the same time something moved her to quicken her pace.

column2: As she drew near the common, she heard the steps more plainly, still soft and swift, and almost wished she had sought refuge in the cottage she had just passed--only it bore no very good character in the neighborhood. When she reached the spot where the paths united, feeling a little at home, she stopped to listen.
column3: As she drew near the common, she heard the steps more plainly, still soft and swift, and almost wished she had sought refuge in the cottage she had just passed-only it bore no very good character in the neighborhood. When she reached the spot where the paths united, feeling a little at home, she stopped to listen.

column2: Behind her were the footsteps plain enough!
column3: Behind her were the footsteps plain enough!

column2: The same moment the clouds thinned about the moon, and a pale light came filtering through upon the common in front of her.
column3: The same moment the clouds thinned about the moon, and a pale light came filtering through upon the common in front of her.

column2: She cast one look over her shoulder, saw something turn a corner in the lane, and sped on again.
column3: She cast one look over her shoulder, saw something turn a corner in the lane, and sped on again.

column2: She would have run, but there was no place of refuge now nearer than the corner of the turnpike-road, and she knew her breath would fail her long before that.
column3: She would have run, but there was no place of refuge now nearer than the corner of the turnpike road, and she knew her breath would fail her long before that.

column2: How lonely and shelterless the common looked!
column3: How lonely and shelterless the common looked!

column2: The soft, swift steps came nearer and nearer.
column3: The soft, swift steps came nearer and nearer.

column2: Was that music she heard?
column3: Was that music she heard?

column2: She dared not stop to listen.
column3: She dared not stop to listen.

column2: But immediately, thereupon, was poured forth on the dim air such a stream of pearly sounds as if all the necklaces of some heavenly choir of woman-angels were broken, and the beads came pelting down in a cataract of hurtless hail.
column3: But immediately, thereupon, was poured forth on the dim air such a stream of pearly sounds as if all the necklaces of some heavenly choir of woman angels were broken, and the beads came pelting down in a cataract of hurtless hail.

column2: From no source could they come save the bow and violin of Joseph Jasper!
column3: From no source could they come save the bow and violin of Joseph Jasper!

column2: Where could he be?
column3: Where could he be?

column2: She was so rejoiced to know that he must be somewhere near, that, for very delight of unsecured safety, she held her peace, and had almost stopped.
column3: She was so rejoiced to know that he must be somewhere near, that, for very delight of unsecured safety, she held her peace, and had almost stopped.

column2: But she ran on again.
column3: But she ran on again.

column2: She was now nigh the ruined hut with which my narrative has made the reader acquainted.
column3: She was now nigh the ruined hut with which my narrative has made the reader acquainted.

column2: In the mean time the moon had been growing out of the clouds, clearer and clearer.
column3: In the mean time the moon had been growing out of the clouds, clearer and clearer.

column2: The hut came in sight.
column3: The hut came in sight.

column2: But the look of it was somehow altered--with an undefinable change, such as might appear on a familiar object in a dream; and leaning against the side of the door stood a figure she could not mistake for another than her musician.
column3: But the look of it was somehow altered-with an undefinable change, such as might appear on a familiar object in a dream; and leaning against the side of the door stood a figure she could not mistake for another than her musician.

column2: Absorbed in his music, he did not see her.
column3: Absorbed in his music, he did not see her.

column2: She called out, "Joseph!
column3: She called out, "Joseph!

column2: Joseph!"
column3: Joseph!"

column2: He started, threw his bow from him, tucked his violin under his arm, and bounded to meet her.
column3: He started, threw his bow from him, tucked his violin under his arm, and bounded to meet her.

column2: She tried to stop, and the same moment to look behind her.
column3: She tried to stop, and the same moment to look behind her.

column2: The consequence was that she fell--but safe in the smith's arms.
column3: The consequence was that she fell-but safe in the smith's arms.

column2: That instant appeared a man running.
column3: That instant appeared a man running.

column2: He half stopped, and, turning from the path, took to the common.
column3: He half stopped, and, turning from the path, took to the common.

column2: Jasper handed his violin to Mary, and darted after him.
column3: Jasper handed his violin to Mary, and darted after him.

column2: The chase did not last a minute; the man was nearly spent.
column3: The chase did not last a minute; the man was nearly spent.

column2: Joseph seized him by the wrist, saw something glitter in his other hand, and turned sick.
column3: Joseph seized him by the wrist, saw something glitter in his other hand, and turned sick.

column2: The fellow had stabbed him.
column3: The fellow had stabbed him.

column2: With indignation, as if it were a snake that had bit him, the blacksmith flung from him the hand he held.
column3: With indignation, as if it were a snake that had bit him, the blacksmith flung from him the hand he held.

column2: The man gave a cry, staggered, recovered himself, and ran.
column3: The man gave a cry, staggered, recovered himself, and ran.

column2: Joseph would have followed again, but fell, and for a minute or two lost consciousness.
column3: Joseph would have followed again, but fell, and for a minute or two lost consciousness.

column2: When he came to himself, Mary was binding up his arm.
column3: When he came to himself, Mary was binding up his arm.

column2: What a fool I am! he said, trying to get up, but yielding at once to Mary's prevention.
column3: What a fool I am! he said, trying to get up, but yielding at once to Mary's prevention.

column2: Ain't it ridic'lous now, miss, that a man of my size, and ready to work a sledge with any smith in Yorkshire, should turn sick for a little bit of a job with a knife?	Ain't it ridic'lous now, miss, that a man of my size, and ready to work a sledge with any smith in Yorkshire, should turn sick for a little bit of a job with a knife?

column2: But my father was just the same, and he was a stronger man than I'm like to be, I fancy."
column3: But my father was just the same, and he was a stronger man than I'm like to be, I fancy."

column2: It is no such wonder as you think, said Mary; "you have lost a good deal of blood."
column3: It is no such wonder as you think, said Mary; "you have lost a good deal of blood."

column2: Her voice faltered.
column3: Her voice faltered.

column2: She had been greatly alarmed--and the more that she had not light enough to get the edges of the wound properly together.
column3: She had been greatly alarmed-and the more that she had not light enough to get the edges of the wound properly together.

column2: You've stopped it--ain't you, miss?
column3: You've stopped it-ain't you, miss?

column2: I think so.
column3: I think so.

column2: Then I'll be after the fellow.
column3: Then I'll be after the fellow.

column2: No, no; you must not attempt it.	No, no; you must not attempt it.

column2: You must lie still awhile.
column3: You must lie still awhile.

column2: But I don't understand it at all!
column3: But I don't understand it at all!

column2: That cottage used to be a mere hovel, without door or window!
column3: That cottage used to be a mere hovel, without door or window!

column2: It can't be you live in it?"
column3: It can't be you live in it?"

column2: Ay, that I do! and it's not a bad place either, answered Joseph. "That's what I went to Yorkshire to get my money for.
column3: Ay, that I do! and it's not a bad place either, answered Joseph. "That's what I went to Yorkshire to get my money for.

column2: It's mine--bought and paid for."
column3: It's mine-bought and paid for."

column2: But what made you think of coming here?
column3: But what made you think of coming here?

column2: Let's go into the smithy--house I won't presume to call it, said Joseph, "though it has a lean-to for the smith--and I'll tell you everything about it.
column3: Let's go into the smithy-house I won't presume to call it, said Joseph, "though it has a lean to for the smith-and I'll tell you everything about it.

column2: But really, miss, you oughtn't to be out like this after dark.
column3: But really, miss, you oughtn't to be out like this after dark.

column2: There's too many vagabonds about."
column3: There's too many vagabonds about."

column2: With but little need of the help Mary yet gave him, Joseph got up, and led her to what was now a respectable little smithy, with forge and bellows and anvil and bucket.
column3: With but little need of the help Mary yet gave him, Joseph got up, and led her to what was now a respectable little smithy, with forge and bellows and anvil and bucket.

column2: Opening a door where had been none, he brought a chair, and making her sit down, began to blow the covered fire on the hearth, where he had not long before "boiled his kettle" for his tea.
column3: Opening a door where had been none, he brought a chair, and making her sit down, began to blow the covered fire on the hearth, where he had not long before "boiled his kettle" for his tea.

column2: Then closing the door, he lighted a candle, and Mary looking about her could scarcely believe the change that had come upon the miserable vacuity.
column3: Then closing the door, he lighted a candle, and Mary looking about her could scarcely believe the change that had come upon the miserable vacuity.

column2: Joseph sat down upon his anvil, and begged to know where she had just been, and how far she had run from the rascal. When he had learned something of the peculiar relations in which Mary stood to the family at Durnmelling, he began to think there might have been something more in the pursuit than a chance ruffianly assault, and the greater were his regrets that he had not secured the miscreant.
column3: Joseph sat down upon his anvil, and begged to know where she had just been, and how far she had run from the rascal. column2: Anyhow, miss, he said, "you'll never come from there alone in the dark again!"
column3: Anyhow, miss, he said, "you'll never come from there alone in the dark again!"

column2: I understand you, Joseph, answered Mary, "for I know you would not have me leave doing what I can for the poor man up there, because of a little danger in the way."
column3: I understand you, Joseph, answered Mary, "for I know you would not have me leave doing what I can for the poor man up there, because of a little danger in the way."

column2: That would be as much as to say you would do the will of God when the devil would let you.
column3: That would be as much as to say you would do the will of God when the devil would let you.

column2: What I mean is, that here am I--your slave, or servant, or soldier, or whatever you may please to call me, ready at your word."
column3: What I mean is, that here am I-your slave, or servant, or soldier, or whatever you may please to call me, ready at your word."

column2: I must not take you from your work, you know, Joseph.
column3: I must not take you from your work, you know, Joseph.

column2: Work's not everything, miss, he answered; "and it's seldom so pressing but that--except I be shoeing a horse--I can leave it when I choose.
column3: Work's not everything, miss, he answered; "and it's seldom so pressing but that-except I be shoeing a horse-I can leave it when I choose.

column2: Any time you want to go anywhere, don't forget as you've got enemies about, and just send for me.
column3: Any time you want to go anywhere, don't forget as you've got enemies about, and just send for me.

column2: You won't have long to wait till I come.
column3: You won't have long to wait till I come.

column2: But I am main sorry the rascal didn't have something to keep him in mind of his manners."
column3: But I am main sorry the rascal didn't have something to keep him in mind of his manners."

column2: Part of this conversation, and a good deal more, passed on their way to Testbridge, whither, as soon as Joseph seemed all right, Mary, who had forgotten her hunger and faintness, insisted on setting out at once.
column3: Part of this conversation, and a good deal more, passed on their way to Testbridge, whither, as soon as Joseph seemed all right, Mary, who had forgotten her hunger and faintness, insisted on setting out at once.

column2: In her turn she questioned Joseph, and learned that, as soon as he knew she was going to settle at Testbridge, he started off to find if possible a place in the neighborhood humble enough to be within his reach, and near enough for the hope of seeing her sometimes, and having what help she might please to give him.
column3: In her turn she questioned Joseph, and learned that, as soon as he knew she was going to settle at Testbridge, he started off to find if possible a place in the neighborhood humble enough to be within his reach, and near enough for the hope of seeing her sometimes, and having what help she might please to give him.

column2: The explanation afforded Mary more pleasure than she cared to show.
column3: The explanation afforded Mary more pleasure than she cared to show.

column2: She had a real friend near her--one ready to help her on her own ground--one who understood her because he understood the things she loved!
column3: She had a real friend near her-one ready to help her on her own ground-one who understood her because he understood the things she loved!

column2: He told her that already he had work enough to keep him going; that the horses he once shod were always brought to him again; that he was at no expense such as in a town; and that he had plenty of time both for his violin and his books.
column3: He told her that already he had work enough to keep him going; that the horses he once shod were always brought to him again; that he was at no expense such as in a town; and that he had plenty of time both for his violin and his books.

column2: When they came to the suburbs, she sent him home, and went straight to Mr. Brett with Mr. Redmain's message.
column3: When they came to the suburbs, she sent him home, and went straight to mr Brett with mr Redmain's message.

column2: He undertook to be at Durnmelling at the time appointed, and to let nothing prevent him from seeing his new client.
column3: He undertook to be at Durnmelling at the time appointed, and to let nothing prevent him from seeing his new client.

column2: CHAPTER LIV.
column3: CHAPTER fifty four.

column2: THE NEXT NIGHT.
column3: THE NEXT NIGHT.

column2: Mr. Bratt found no difficulty in the way of the interview, for Mr. Redmain had given Mewks instructions he dared not disobey: his master had often ailed, and recovered again, and he must not venture too far! As soon as he had shown the visitor into the room he was dismissed, but not before he had satisfied himself that he was a lawyer.
column3: mr Bratt found no difficulty in the way of the interview, for mr Redmain had given Mewks instructions he dared not disobey: his master had often ailed, and recovered again, and he must not venture too far! As soon as he had shown the visitor into the room he was dismissed, but not before he had satisfied himself that he was a lawyer.

column2: He carried the news at once to Sepia, and it wrought no little anxiety in the house.
column3: He carried the news at once to Sepia, and it wrought no little anxiety in the house.

column2: There was a will already in existence, and no ground for thinking a change in it boded anything good.
column3: There was a will already in existence, and no ground for thinking a change in it boded anything good.

column2: Mr. Mortimer never deigned to share his thoughts, anxieties, or hopes with any of his people; but the ladies met in deep consultation, although of course there was nothing to be done.
column3: mr Mortimer never deigned to share his thoughts, anxieties, or hopes with any of his people; but the ladies met in deep consultation, although of course there was nothing to be done.

column2: The only operative result was that it let Sepia know how, though for reasons somewhat different, her anxiety was shared by the others: unlike theirs, her sole desire was--_not_ to be mentioned in the will: that could only be for the sake of leaving her a substantial curse!
column3: The only operative result was that it let Sepia know how, though for reasons somewhat different, her anxiety was shared by the others: unlike theirs, her sole desire was-underscore not underscore to be mentioned in the will: that could only be for the sake of leaving her a substantial curse!

column2: Mr. Redmain's utter silence, after, as she well knew, having gathered damning facts to her discredit, had long convinced her he was but biding his time.
column3: mr Redmain's utter silence, after, as she well knew, having gathered damning facts to her discredit, had long convinced her he was but biding his time.

column2: Certain she was he would not depart this life without leaving his opinion of her and the proofs of its justice behind him, carrying weight as the affidavit of a dying man.
column3: Certain she was he would not depart this life without leaving his opinion of her and the proofs of its justice behind him, carrying weight as the affidavit of a dying man.

column2: Also she knew Hesper well enough to be certain that, however she might delight in opposition to the desire of her husband, she would for the sake of no one carry that opposition to a point where it became injurious to her interests.
column3: Also she knew Hesper well enough to be certain that, however she might delight in opposition to the desire of her husband, she would for the sake of no one carry that opposition to a point where it became injurious to her interests.

column2: Sepia's one thought therefore was: could not something be done to prevent the making of another will, or the leaving of any fresh document behind him?
column3: Sepia's one thought therefore was: could not something be done to prevent the making of another will, or the leaving of any fresh document behind him?

column2: What he might already have done, she could nowise help; what he might yet do, it would be well to prevent.
column3: What he might already have done, she could nowise help; what he might yet do, it would be well to prevent.

column2: Once more, therefore, she impressed upon Mewks, and that in the names of Mrs. Redmain and Lady Margaret, as well as in her own person, the absolute necessity of learning as much as possible of what might pass between his master and the lawyer.
column3: Once more, therefore, she impressed upon Mewks, and that in the names of mrs Redmain and Lady Margaret, as well as in her own person, the absolute necessity of learning as much as possible of what might pass between his master and the lawyer.
